posts.name: Charles
posts.cooked: We are trying to stack Eva foam tiles for our bumpers, and we are curious what people are using to adhere the different layers together.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: We are using 3M super 77 spray adhesive. Other spray adhesives should work as well
We used Gorilla brand spray adhesive and I was told it worked well. @ekruzyk

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Keep in mind that in the past, a very common way of keeping the pool noodles â€˜in placeâ€™ on the backing was just to duct tape them there.  It works just as well with the EVA foam.  However, we also used the 3M spray.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: double sided carpet tape also comes to mind

posts.name: Jimmy McCosker
posts.cooked: we used contact cement with incredible success so far

posts.name: Will C
posts.cooked: Weâ€™re just wrapping gaffers tape around the foam and backing to hold it all together

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design

posts.custom_user_title: 3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design

posts.name: Bailey
posts.cooked:
We were going to use Super77â€¦

Until we found Super74 !

Looks similar to the 77, but is designed for foams & fabrics. We havenâ€™t used it yet, but knowing how nasty (in a good way) the Super77 adhesive is, weâ€™re hoping the version made specifically for foam & fabrics will be even better

posts.name: Casey Stahl - 2358 - Robot Repairman (Mentor)
posts.cooked:
Weâ€™re used double sided carpet tape.  Worked well and was about $13 at our local home depot for a 75 ft. roll.

We got the information from this CD thread, which has many different options.

Let's Talk About Squishing Foam Technical Discussion

I heartily recommend this tape:

$15.97

posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked: Those are some beautiful bumpers. Looks awesome you guys!

posts.name: Clay
posts.cooked: We used Barge Cement, a brand of contact cement.  It was foul, and we had to run fans and open doors, but lordy did it work.

posts.name: Chase Eid
posts.cooked: We use a heatgun and slightly melt both

posts.name: Brandon
posts.cooked: We used this as we had some left over from doing note repairs from last year. Barge

link_counts.title: Amazon.com: Barge All Purpose Cement, Neutral, Quart, 32 fl oz (Packaging May Vary), : Industrial & Scientific

posts.name: Kevin Clark
posts.cooked: Weâ€™re using 3M High Strength 90 for laminating foam to get to a 3â€ billet that we then machine. When we stick the billet on our router bed we use 3M 77 to stick it down to a layer of tape. Both have been working well for us.

posts.name: Kevin Forbes
posts.cooked: Let us know how that goes! Iâ€™ve used both extensively at a previous job, and 77 tended to work well for smoother, closed cell foam while 74 was best for filling in larger gaps between open cell foam.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked: We had good initial success using expanding foam adhesive (specifically adhesive, not expanding spray foam insulation) to bond tiles together. It appears to have filled the gaps between tiles due to tread patterns pretty well.

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked: Can confirm: this works great for polyethylene foam, but not sure how it works for other types.
